I was on the third day of volleyball tryouts, confident that I'd make the A team. I tossed the ball up, but it was a poor toss. “Where is my dad? As she walked out, I wrote a letter saying, “Dad, you could have said goodbye, but you left.” Weeks passed, and there was no sign of a letter from him. My brothers and sisters got them, but not me. I felt forgotten. “Why haven't I gotten a letter from Dad, but everyone else did?” I asked. “I don't know,” my mom said. I'd send him a letter every day, but I never got one back. I started to wonder why. Did he hate me? Did he not want to talk to me? Had he forgotten about me? One day, I heard someone yell, “You have mail!” I ran down the stairs to the kitchen. There was something on the counter for me. It had my name on it, but it didn't say who it was from. “Who is it from?” I asked. “Open it and find out,” my mom said. I slowly opened the letter and started reading. “Don't worry. I haven't written yet, but maybe this will make up for it. I love you more than anything in the world, Daddy.” I opened the package, and it was a picture of us and his army sack with all the letters I'd sent him. All of them were unopened, and there was a note in all the envelopes. That very night, he called and said, “But I love you no matter what. See you soon.”

Finally, we reached the reception. I was so glad to be there, even though I hate weddings. When we got home, @CAPS4 mom asked, "Did you have patience?" I asked, "Patience?" Then I said, "Yes, I guess I did. Even the car ride was kind of okay." @CAPS4 mom said, "Really? You're not usually the patient type." I replied, "Yes," and I felt proud of myself.

A few weeks ago, we held a garage sale and a mom - to - mom sale. I had to exercise patience because of the customers driving by during the mom - to - mom sale and while waiting for people to visit our table. At the garage sale, I also had a lemonade stand. Overall, we made a good amount of money from both sales. However, we still had some items left over that we had to take home and donate. The sales were enjoyable, but we had to put in a lot of work. We had to price all the items and then wait for customers. Sometimes, I was happy when people bought our stuff. We really had a great time organizing the mom - to - mom sale and the garage sale. I believe we did a pretty good job. Although we sold a lot, there were still some items that we needed to pack up and donate. Despite the hard work, I really liked being part of these sales. In conclusion, the experience was both challenging and rewarding.
